item.title: How to Use Pulsar SQL Effectively
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article explores how Pulsar SQL queries data and the components involved. It also walks through an SQL query example.

item.title: Understanding the Roles of Zookeeper and Bookkeeper in Pulsar
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Although they have some similarities, ZooKeeper and BookKeeper provide different administrative services in Pulsar. This article will help you to understand how ZooKeeper and BookKeeper work, the roles these components play in Pulsar, and the differences between ZooKeeper and BookKeeper, highlighting use cases where each component is particularly useful.

item.title: Apache Pulsar Versus Kinesis
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article offers a high-level comparison of Pulsar and Kinesis, contrasting important factors such as cost, scalability, and performance. exploring relevant use-cases that highlight the capabilities and differentiators of each.

item.title: A Crash Course in Distributed Pub-Sub Messaging With Apache Pulsar
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Messaging is essential to modern life and how you get things done. So, without messaging, how would the world look? This question may appear far-fetched, but it’s a significant concern for computing. How do you talk to software? What is the mechanism through which software programs communicate with each other? How does software speak to you?

item.title: Apache BookKeeper Disk Usage With Apache Pulsar
item.author: Andrey Yegorov

item.title: Comparing Apache Pulsar Streaming and Kafka Streaming
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article examines how Pulsar and Kafka approach streaming by discussing their architectures and services. After briefly reviewing the definition of streaming, we’ll start our discussion with Kafka, since it’s the tool against which all others in the category are compared. We’ll then outline how Pulsar differs from and solves the problems Kafka leaves unaddressed — specifically, how it handles streaming.

item.title: Comparing Apache Pulsar and RabbitMQ
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Let’s take an in-depth look at the similarities and differences between Pulsar and RabbitMQ

item.title: Apache Pulsar Multi Tenancy Explained
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Apache Pulsar was built from scratch to focus on multi-tenancy as a founding principle. To manage multi-tenancy aspects within a Pulsar instance, Pulsar supports a concept called tenants.

item.title: How Schemas Make the World Go Round
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: The Apache Pulsar Schema is one of the most critical components of Apache Pulsar, an open-source distributed system messaging and streaming platform. In this article, we’ll explore the role of schemas in data streaming and how JSON, Avro, and Apache Pulsar work together to make edge computing possible.

item.title: Where Is the Edge?
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article will explore the edge, how it relates to performance-sensitive devices such as IoT devices, and how Apache Pulsar can get you closer to the edge. But first, you need to understand what — and where — the edge is.

item.title: REST Versus Event Driven Architecture - Why It's Time to Switch From Request Based Architecture
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article introduces REST and event-driven architectures and explains why organizations should move to an EDA to maximize customer satisfaction.

item.title: Why Managed Apache Pulsar Is the Right Choice
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: In this article, we’ll explore why and how using a managed Apache Pulsar service saves you time and energy by reducing toil. We’ll explore some partners that offer a Pulsar as a service solution and highlight their strengths and challenges to help you select a managed service to use.

item.title: The Difference Between Persistent and Non Persistent Topics in Apache Pulsar
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article will explore what Pulsar topics are, the differences between persistent and non-persistent topics in Apache Pulsar, and review some example use cases for both methods.

item.title: Integrating Apache Druid With Apache Pulsar
item.author: Hellmar Becker
item.description: With companies adopting the event streaming pattern, analytics has to become more "realtime" too. A great database for event analytics is Apache Druid. Druid connects natively to various event streaming systems such as Kafka and AWS Kinesis.

item.title: How Pulsar and Kafka Partitions Work (And How They Differ)
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Both Pulsar and Kafka aim to increase the amount of data that can be consumed and processed by horizontal scaling — spreading data across many partitions. This is possible thanks to parallel processing, wherein the data producer writes to multiple partitions and the consumer reads them.

item.title: How Pulsar Can Help IoT Avoid the Internet - Event Streaming at the Edge
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article explains how performance-sensitive IoT applications can improve their performance with event streaming at the edge using Apache Pulsar.

item.title: Do I Have Time to Learn Event Streaming?
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: In this article, we’ll explore what event streaming is, how it works, and discuss the growing importance of event streaming. Then, we’ll highlight how we can simplify the task of learning event streaming with the help of Apache Pulsar.

item.title: Moving from Java Message Service (JMS) to Apache Pulsar
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Let’s explore some advantages and challenges of moving from JMS to Pulsar.

item.title: Apache Pulsar Versus Apache Kafka
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: In this article, we'll evaluate the features, architectures, performance, and use cases of Apache Pulsar versus Kafka, to help you decide which is the better solution for you.

item.title: Apache Pulsar Schema versus Schemaless — Who’s the Winner?
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: In this article, we’ll examine how Pulsar Schemas work and contrast them with schemaless systems to determine the best approach. We’ll also demonstrate how to use Java clients with Pulsar.

item.title: Understanding the Differences Between Message Queues and Streaming
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Almost any application that requires real-time or near-real-time data processing benefits from having a message queue or streaming data processing component in its architecture. Online food ordering apps, e-commerce sites, media streaming services, and online gaming are straightforward examples. But weather apps, smart cars, health status apps with smartwatch technology, or anything Internet of things (IoT) typically rely on a message queue or streaming engine as well.

item.title: Pulsar: Queuing and Streaming - An All in One Messaging System
item.author: Ivan Garcia
item.description: I would also like to focus this reading on what is Pulsar and how it works under its own merits rather than comparing it against apache Kafka. I am taking this approach as there is plenty literature doing this already and because from a messaging system architecture both of these paradigms, up to a point, are different.

item.title: Pulsar: Building a High Available Messaging System - A Step by Step CookBook
item.author: Ivan Garcia
item.description: This guide will walk you step by step to deploy a Pulsar instance with one cluster but prepared already to extend the deployment further, including more Pulsar clusters at a later stage.

item.title: Apache Pulsar Transactions API Deep Dives
item.description: Transactions are an API in Apache Pulsar that enables atomic operations among pulsar consumers and producers. This talk covers the motivating factors for Transactions in a system like Apache Pulsar, deep dives into the transactions API, and walks through some examples of using Transactions with the pulsar4s client.

item.title: Internals of Stream Processing
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Stream Processing Systems (SPSs) are an integral part of modern data-intensive companies. In a world where streams are becoming king, they are commonly employed for much more than data analytics. Yet, most of developers only use them and have never dove deep into the internals of the system.

item.title: Using Open Source Software to improve Streaming on the Edge
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: IoT devices are expected to number in the billions, each device enabled by one or more sensors, generating data about the device and its surrounding environment. Analyzing this data using machine learning (ML)/Artificial Intelligence (AI) models, for example, frequently requires transferring this data to the cloud.

item.title: Apache Bookkeeper and Apache Zookeeper for Apache Pulsar
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Enrico Olivelli speaks to the Japan Apache Pulsar User Group about how Apache Pulsar uses Apache ZooKeeper and Apache BookKeeper, with a particular focus on how Pulsar guarantees consistency even in spite of common failures in distributed systems.

item.title: Apache Pulsar Deep Dive an End-to-End View of the Data Flow
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Enrico Olivelli gives us a tour of how data moves from the Producer to the Consumer.

item.title: Apache Pulsar and Machine Learning
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Simba Khadder shared his insights on why Pulsar Distributed Messaging system and its separation of storage and brokerage layers are great fit for AI/ML applications.

item.title: Leveraging Pulsar's Next Gen Streaming Capabilities from a JavaEE Application
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: In this session you will see how to use Pulsar in a JakartaEE Web Application deployed on Apache TomEE via the JMS/EJB API, without installing any additional components to your cluster.

item.title: Running Apache Pulsar in Multiple Regions
item.author: Apache Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: Zeke Dean walks us through how to run Apache Pulsar in multiple regions

item.title: How To Enable Observability Into Apache Pulsar
item.author: Pulsar Neighborhood
item.description: This article explores how to enable observability for your Pulsar environment using Prometheus and Grafana, starting from a demo standalone Pulsar cluster. You then learn how to import sample Grafana dashboards for Pulsar from GitHub. Finally, once everything is up and running, we zoom in on several of the standard and crucial metrics for building your observability dashboards on Pulsar.

item.title: Managing a Pulsar cluster with Terraform
item.author: David Dieruf
item.description: Use a community supported Terraform provider to manage Pulsar clusters
